div.p: Colonial Secretary's Office - letters received, acc. 36, vol. 681, ff. 13-14, State Records Office of Western Australia, Perth.

I thank you very much, dear Mr Barlee, for having secured for me the foliage of the Grevillea, of which I knew only the fruit. I must ask you now to try to get from your correspondent the flowers also, without which it will be impossible to determine the species. Your correspondent failed however entirely in recognizing the Molloya, for which he sent an Acacia not dissimilar in foliage. He will recognize the former by the boatshaped seed vessel, over an inch long. The flowers are likely to resemble those of a Grevillea[.]
editorial addition.
Is the fruit of the Grevillea before alluded to quite harmless? Mr C. Gill (in the note with the specimen) says it is relished by the natives. There is certainly an allied Queensland tree and an other [one] in Chili,
sic.
which yield hazel like kernels.

His Lordship, the Bishop, will have got my Pineseeds
sic.
by last mail

It would have been all right enough with the Eucla Expedition if the Shooner had stayed a month or two with the party, until by repeated dashes some permanent inland water had been found, if even 100 miles off.

If any vessel goes to the harbour, try (please) to let Maxwell go with them to make a full collection of plants. As I often said, the spot is most interesting , as W. & E. forms of vegetation so much meet there. It is the geography of plants which need in W. A. so much attention yet.
I believe that the Grevillea is very much earlier in flower than Mr Gill thinks.

div.p:
I will write to Mr Forrest about further field work
MS annotation by Barlee on 9 February 1871: 'My dear Hayes | Will you see if anything further can be done in the way of getting what Dr. Müeller [sic.] wants? | You can return his letter.' On 23 February 1871 G. H. Laurence minuted: 'Dear Fred, | I have written to Gill, who no doubt will do what is in his power to get what Dr. M wants.'
